Note 2: 5A002.a does not control any of the following items, or specially designed “information security” components therefor:

  1. Smart cards and smart card 'readers/writers' as follows:

    1. a.1. A smart card or an electronically readable personal document (e.g., token coin, e-passport) that meets any of the following:

  2. 1.a. The cryptographic capability meets all of the following:

    1. a.1.a.1. It is restricted for use in any of the following:

  3. 1.a.1.a. Equipment or systems, not described by 5A002.a.1, 5A002.a.2, 5A002.a.3, 5A002.a.4;

  4. a.1.a.1.b. Equipment or systems, not using 'cryptography for data confidentiality' having a 'described security algorithm'; or

  5. a.1.a.1.c. Equipment or systems, excluded from 5A002.a by entries b. to f. of this Note; and

    1. a.1.a.2. It cannot be reprogrammed for any other use; or

  6. a.1.b. Having all of the following:

    1. a.1.b.1. It is specially designed and limited to allow protection of 'personal data' stored within;

    2. a.1.b.2. Has been, or can only be, personalized for public or commercial transactions or individual identification; and

    3. a.1.b.3. Where the cryptographic capability is not user-accessible;

content.text: Technical Note to paragraph a.2 of Note 2: 'Readers/writers' include equipment that communicates with smart cards or electronically readable documents through a network. b. Cryptographic equipment specially designed and limited for banking use or 'money transactions';

content.html:
Technical Note to paragraph b. of Note 2: 'Money transactions' in 5A002 Note 2 paragraph b. includes the collection and settlement of fares or credit functions.

  1. Portable or mobile radiotelephones for civil use (e.g., for use with commercial civil cellular radio communication systems) that are not capable of transmitting encrypted data directly to another radiotelephone or equipment (other than Radio Access Network (RAN) equipment), nor of passing encrypted data through RAN equipment (e.g., Radio Network Controller (RNC) or Base Station Controller (BSC));

  2. Cordless telephone equipment not capable of end-to-end encryption where the maximum effective range of unboosted cordless operation (i.e., a single, unrelayed hop between terminal and home base station) is less than 400 meters according to the manufacturer's specifications;

  3. Portable or mobile radiotelephones and similar client wireless devices for civil use, that implement only published or commercial cryptographic standards (except for anti-piracy functions, which may be non-published) and also meet the provisions of paragraphs a.2 to a.4 of the Cryptography Note (Note 3 in Category 5 - Part 2), that have been customized for a specific civil industry application with features that do not affect the cryptographic functionality of these original non-customized devices;

  4. Items, where the “information security” functionality is limited to wireless “personal area network” functionality, meeting all of the following:

    1. f.1. Implement only published or commercial cryptographic standards; and

    2. f.2. The cryptographic capability is limited to a nominal operating range not exceeding 30 meters according to the manufacturer's specifications, or not exceeding 100 meters according to the manufacturer's specifications for equipment that cannot interconnect with more than seven devices;

  5. Mobile telecommunications Radio Access Network (RAN) equipment designed for civil use, which also meet the provisions of paragraphs a.2 to a.4 of the Cryptography Note (Note 3 in Category 5 - Part 2), having an RF output power limited to 0.1W (20 dBm) or less, and supporting 16 or fewer concurrent users;

  6. Routers, switches or relays, where the “information security” functionality is limited to the tasks of “Operations, Administration or Maintenance” (“OAM”) implementing only published or commercial cryptographic standards; or

  7. General purpose computing equipment or servers, where the “information security” functionality meets all of the following:

    1. i.1. Uses only published or commercial cryptographic standards; and

    2. i.2. Is any of the following:

  8. i.2.a. Integral to a CPU that meets the provisions of Note 3 in Category 5 - Part 2;

  9. i.2.b. Integral to an operating system that is not specified by 5D002; or

  10. i.2.c. Limited to “OAM” of the equipment.

Items, where the “information security” functionality is limited to wireless “personal area network” functionality, meeting all of the following: f.1. Implement only published or commercial cryptographic standards; and f.2. The cryptographic capability is limited to a nominal operating range not exceeding 30 meters according to the manufacturer's specifications, or not exceeding 100 meters according to the manufacturer's specifications for equipment that cannot interconnect with more than seven devices; g. content.html: Technical Notes:
content.text: Technical Notes:

content.html: 1. For the purposes of 5A002.a, 'cryptography for data confidentiality' means “cryptography” that employs digital techniques and performs any cryptographic function other than any of the following:
content.text: 1. For the purposes of 5A002.a, 'cryptography for data confidentiality' means “cryptography” that employs digital techniques and performs any cryptographic function other than any of the following:

content.html: 1.a. “Authentication;”
content.text: 1.a. “Authentication;”

content.html: 1.b. Digital signature;
content.text: 1.b. Digital signature;

content.html: 1.c. Data integrity;
content.text: 1.c. Data integrity;

content.html: 1.d. Non-repudiation;
content.text: 1.d. Non-repudiation;

content.html: 1.e. Digital rights management, including the execution of copy-protected “software;”
content.text: 1.e. Digital rights management, including the execution of copy-protected “software;”

content.html: 1.f. Encryption or decryption in support of entertainment, mass commercial broadcasts or medical records management; or
content.text: 1.f. Encryption or decryption in support of entertainment, mass commercial broadcasts or medical records management; or

content.html: 1.g. Key management in support of any function described in paragraphs 1.a to 1.f of this Technical Note paragraph 1.
content.text: 1.g. Key management in support of any function described in paragraphs 1.a to 1.f of this Technical Note paragraph 1.

content.html: 2. For the purposes of 5A002.a, 'described security algorithm' means any of the following:
content.text: 2. For the purposes of 5A002.a, 'described security algorithm' means any of the following:

content.html: 2.a. A “symmetric algorithm” employing a key length in excess of 56 bits, not including parity bits; or
content.text: 2.a. A “symmetric algorithm” employing a key length in excess of 56 bits, not including parity bits; or

content.html: 2.b. An “asymmetric algorithm” where the security of the algorithm is based on any of the following:
content.text: 2.b. An “asymmetric algorithm” where the security of the algorithm is based on any of the following:

content.html: 2.b.1. Factorization of integers in excess of 512 bits (e.g., RSA);
content.text: 2.b.1. Factorization of integers in excess of 512 bits (e.g., RSA);

content.html: 2.b.2. Computation of discrete logarithms in a multiplicative group of a finite field of size greater than 512 bits (e.g., Diffie-Hellman over Z/pZ); or
content.text: 2.b.2. Computation of discrete logarithms in a multiplicative group of a finite field of size greater than 512 bits (e.g., Diffie-Hellman over Z/pZ); or

content.html: 2.b.3. Discrete logarithms in a group other than mentioned in paragraph 2.b.2 of this Technical Note in excess of 112 bits (e.g., Diffie-Hellman over an elliptic curve); or
content.text: 2.b.3. Discrete logarithms in a group other than mentioned in paragraph 2.b.2 of this Technical Note in excess of 112 bits (e.g., Diffie-Hellman over an elliptic curve); or

content.html: 2.c. An “asymmetric algorithm” where the security of the algorithm is based on any of the following:
content.text: 2.c. An “asymmetric algorithm” where the security of the algorithm is based on any of the following:

content.html: 2.c.1. Shortest vector or closest vector problems associated with lattices (e.g., NewHope, Frodo, NTRUEncrypt, Kyber, Titanium);
content.text: 2.c.1. Shortest vector or closest vector problems associated with lattices (e.g., NewHope, Frodo, NTRUEncrypt, Kyber, Titanium);

content.html: 2.c.2. Finding isogenies between Supersingular elliptic curves (e.g., Supersingular Isogeny Key Encapsulation); or
content.text: 2.c.2. Finding isogenies between Supersingular elliptic curves (e.g., Supersingular Isogeny Key Encapsulation); or

content.html: 2.c.3. Decoding random codes (e.g., McEliece, Niederreiter).
content.text: 2.c.3. Decoding random codes (e.g., McEliece, Niederreiter).

content.html: Technical Note: An algorithm described by Technical Note 2.c. may be referred to as being post-quantum, quantum-safe or quantum-resistant.
content.text: Technical Note: An algorithm described by Technical Note 2.c. may be referred to as being post-quantum, quantum-safe or quantum-resistant.

content.html:
Note 1: Details of items must be accessible and provided upon request, in order to establish any of the following:

  1. Whether the item meets the criteria of 5A002.a.1, 5A002.a.2, 5A002.a.3, 5A002.a.4; or

  2. Whether the cryptographic capability for data confidentiality specified by 5A002.a is usable without “cryptographic activation.”
content.text: Note 1: Details of items must be accessible and provided upon request, in order to establish any of the following: a. Whether the item meets the criteria of 5A002.a.1, 5A002.a.2, 5A002.a.3, 5A002.a.4; or b. Whether the cryptographic capability for data confidentiality specified by 5A002.a is usable without “cryptographic activation.”

content.text: Technical Notes:

content.html: 1. For the purposes of 5A002.a, 'cryptography for data confidentiality' means “cryptography” that employs digital techniques and performs any cryptographic function other than any of the following:
content.text: 1. For the purposes of 5A002.a, 'cryptography for data confidentiality' means “cryptography” that employs digital techniques and performs any cryptographic function other than any of the following:

content.html: 1.a. “Authentication;”
content.text: 1.a. “Authentication;”

content.html: 1.b. Digital signature;
content.text: 1.b. Digital signature;

content.html: 1.c. Data integrity;
content.text: 1.c. Data integrity;

content.html: 1.d. Non-repudiation;
content.text: 1.d. Non-repudiation;

content.html: 1.e. Digital rights management, including the execution of copy-protected “software;”
content.text: 1.e. Digital rights management, including the execution of copy-protected “software;”

content.html: 1.f. Encryption or decryption in support of entertainment, mass commercial broadcasts or medical records management; or
content.text: 1.f. Encryption or decryption in support of entertainment, mass commercial broadcasts or medical records management; or

content.html: 1.g. Key management in support of any function described in paragraphs 1.a to 1.f of this Technical Note paragraph 1.
content.text: 1.g. Key management in support of any function described in paragraphs 1.a to 1.f of this Technical Note paragraph 1.

content.html: 2. For the purposes of 5A002.a, 'described security algorithm' means any of the following:
content.text: 2. For the purposes of 5A002.a, 'described security algorithm' means any of the following:

content.html: 2.a. A “symmetric algorithm” employing a key length in excess of 56 bits, not including parity bits; or
content.text: 2.a. A “symmetric algorithm” employing a key length in excess of 56 bits, not including parity bits; or

content.html: 2.b. An “asymmetric algorithm” where the security of the algorithm is based on any of the following:
content.text: 2.b. An “asymmetric algorithm” where the security of the algorithm is based on any of the following:

content.html: 2.b.1. Factorization of integers in excess of 512 bits (e.g., RSA);
content.text: 2.b.1. Factorization of integers in excess of 512 bits (e.g., RSA);

content.html: 2.b.2. Computation of discrete logarithms in a multiplicative group of a finite field of size greater than 512 bits (e.g., Diffie-Hellman over Z/pZ); or
content.text: 2.b.2. Computation of discrete logarithms in a multiplicative group of a finite field of size greater than 512 bits (e.g., Diffie-Hellman over Z/pZ); or

content.html: 2.b.3. Discrete logarithms in a group other than mentioned in paragraph 2.b.2 of this Technical Note in excess of 112 bits (e.g., Diffie-Hellman over an elliptic curve); or
content.text: 2.b.3. Discrete logarithms in a group other than mentioned in paragraph 2.b.2 of this Technical Note in excess of 112 bits (e.g., Diffie-Hellman over an elliptic curve); or

content.html: 2.c. An “asymmetric algorithm” where the security of the algorithm is based on any of the following:
content.text: 2.c. An “asymmetric algorithm” where the security of the algorithm is based on any of the following:

content.html: 2.c.1. Shortest vector or closest vector problems associated with lattices (e.g., NewHope, Frodo, NTRUEncrypt, Kyber, Titanium);
content.text: 2.c.1. Shortest vector or closest vector problems associated with lattices (e.g., NewHope, Frodo, NTRUEncrypt, Kyber, Titanium);

content.html: 2.c.2. Finding isogenies between Supersingular elliptic curves (e.g., Supersingular Isogeny Key Encapsulation); or
content.text: 2.c.2. Finding isogenies between Supersingular elliptic curves (e.g., Supersingular Isogeny Key Encapsulation); or

content.html: 2.c.3. Decoding random codes (e.g., McEliece, Niederreiter).
content.text: 2.c.3. Decoding random codes (e.g., McEliece, Niederreiter).

content.html: Technical Note: An algorithm described by Technical Note 2.c. may be referred to as being post-quantum, quantum-safe or quantum-resistant.
content.text: Technical Note: An algorithm described by Technical Note 2.c. may be referred to as being post-quantum, quantum-safe or quantum-resistant.

content.html:
Technical Note to paragraph b. of Note 2: 'Money transactions' in 5A002 Note 2 paragraph b. includes the collection and settlement of fares or credit functions.

  1. Portable or mobile radiotelephones for civil use (e.g., for use with commercial civil cellular radio communication systems) that are not capable of transmitting encrypted data directly to another radiotelephone or equipment (other than Radio Access Network (RAN) equipment), nor of passing encrypted data through RAN equipment (e.g., Radio Network Controller (RNC) or Base Station Controller (BSC));

  2. Cordless telephone equipment not capable of end-to-end encryption where the maximum effective range of unboosted cordless operation (i.e., a single, unrelayed hop between terminal and home base station) is less than 400 meters according to the manufacturer's specifications;

  3. Portable or mobile radiotelephones and similar client wireless devices for civil use, that implement only published or commercial cryptographic standards (except for anti-piracy functions, which may be non-published) and also meet the provisions of paragraphs a.2 to a.4 of the Cryptography Note (Note 3 in Category 5 - Part 2), that have been customized for a specific civil industry application with features that do not affect the cryptographic functionality of these original non-customized devices;

  4. Items, where the “information security” functionality is limited to wireless “personal area network” functionality, meeting all of the following:

    1. f.1. Implement only published or commercial cryptographic standards; and

    2. f.2. The cryptographic capability is limited to a nominal operating range not exceeding 30 meters according to the manufacturer's specifications, or not exceeding 100 meters according to the manufacturer's specifications for equipment that cannot interconnect with more than seven devices;

  5. Mobile telecommunications Radio Access Network (RAN) equipment designed for civil use, which also meet the provisions of paragraphs a.2 to a.4 of the Cryptography Note (Note 3 in Category 5 - Part 2), having an RF output power limited to 0.1W (20 dBm) or less, and supporting 16 or fewer concurrent users;

  6. Routers, switches or relays, where the “information security” functionality is limited to the tasks of “Operations, Administration or Maintenance” (“OAM”) implementing only published or commercial cryptographic standards; or

  7. General purpose computing equipment or servers, where the “information security” functionality meets all of the following:

    1. i.1. Uses only published or commercial cryptographic standards; and

    2. i.2. Is any of the following:

  8. i.2.a. Integral to a CPU that meets the provisions of Note 3 in Category 5 - Part 2;

  9. i.2.b. Integral to an operating system that is not specified by 5D002; or

  10. i.2.c. Limited to “OAM” of the equipment.

  1. Portable or mobile radiotelephones for civil use (e.g., for use with commercial civil cellular radio communication systems) that are not capable of transmitting encrypted data directly to another radiotelephone or equipment (other than Radio Access Network (RAN) equipment), nor of passing encrypted data through RAN equipment (e.g., Radio Network Controller (RNC) or Base Station Controller (BSC));

  2. Cordless telephone equipment not capable of end-to-end encryption where the maximum effective range of unboosted cordless operation (i.e., a single, unrelayed hop between terminal and home base station) is less than 400 meters according to the manufacturer's specifications;

  3. Portable or mobile radiotelephones and similar client wireless devices for civil use, that implement only published or commercial cryptographic standards (except for anti-piracy functions, which may be non-published) and also meet the provisions of paragraphs a.2 to a.4 of the Cryptography Note (Note 3 in Category 5 - Part 2), that have been customized for a specific civil industry application with features that do not affect the cryptographic functionality of these original non-customized devices;

  4. Items, where the “information security” functionality is limited to wireless “personal area network” functionality, meeting all of the following:

    1. f.1. Implement only published or commercial cryptographic standards; and

    2. f.2. The cryptographic capability is limited to a nominal operating range not exceeding 30 meters according to the manufacturer's specifications, or not exceeding 100 meters according to the manufacturer's specifications for equipment that cannot interconnect with more than seven devices;

  5. Mobile telecommunications Radio Access Network (RAN) equipment designed for civil use, which also meet the provisions of paragraphs a.2 to a.4 of the Cryptography Note (Note 3 in Category 5 - Part 2), having an RF output power limited to 0.1W (20 dBm) or less, and supporting 16 or fewer concurrent users;

  6. Routers, switches or relays, where the “information security” functionality is limited to the tasks of “Operations, Administration or Maintenance” (“OAM”) implementing only published or commercial cryptographic standards;

  7. General purpose computing equipment or servers, where the “information security” functionality meets all of the following:

    1. i.1. Uses only published or commercial cryptographic standards; and

    2. i.2. Is any of the following:

  8. i.2.a. Integral to a CPU that meets the provisions of Note 3 in Category 5 - Part 2;

  9. i.2.b. Integral to an operating system that is not specified by 5D002; or

  10. i.2.c. Limited to “OAM” of the equipment; or

    2. j.1.a.2. The device is limited to a specific 'connected civil industry application'; or

  13. j.1.b. Networking equipment meeting all of the following:

    1. j.1.b.1. Being specially designed to communicate with the devices specified by paragraph j.1.a above; and

    2. j.1.b.2. The “information security” functionality is limited to supporting the 'connected civil industry application' of devices specified by paragraph j.1.a above, or the tasks of “OAM” of this networking equipment or of other items specified by paragraph j. of this Note; and

    3. j.2. Where the “information security” functionality implements only published or commercial cryptographic standards, and the cryptographic functionality cannot easily be changed by the user.

content.html: Technical Notes:
content.text: Technical Notes:

content.html: 1. For the purposes of 5A002.a, 'cryptography for data confidentiality' means “cryptography” that employs digital techniques and performs any cryptographic function other than any of the following:
content.text: 1. For the purposes of 5A002.a, 'cryptography for data confidentiality' means “cryptography” that employs digital techniques and performs any cryptographic function other than any of the following:

content.html: 1.a. “Authentication;”
content.text: 1.a. “Authentication;”

content.html: 1.b. Digital signature;
content.text: 1.b. Digital signature;

content.html: 1.c. Data integrity;
content.text: 1.c. Data integrity;

content.html: 1.d. Non-repudiation;
content.text: 1.d. Non-repudiation;

content.html: 1.e. Digital rights management, including the execution of copy-protected “software;”
content.text: 1.e. Digital rights management, including the execution of copy-protected “software;”

content.html: 1.f. Encryption or decryption in support of entertainment, mass commercial broadcasts or medical records management; or
content.text: 1.f. Encryption or decryption in support of entertainment, mass commercial broadcasts or medical records management; or

content.html: 1.g. Key management in support of any function described in paragraphs 1.a to 1.f of this Technical Note paragraph 1.
content.text: 1.g. Key management in support of any function described in paragraphs 1.a to 1.f of this Technical Note paragraph 1.

content.html: 2. For the purposes of 5A002.a, 'described security algorithm' means any of the following:
content.text: 2. For the purposes of 5A002.a, 'described security algorithm' means any of the following:

content.html: 2.a. A “symmetric algorithm” employing a key length in excess of 56 bits, not including parity bits;
content.text: 2.a. A “symmetric algorithm” employing a key length in excess of 56 bits, not including parity bits;

content.html: 2.b. An “asymmetric algorithm” where the security of the algorithm is based on any of the following:
content.text: 2.b. An “asymmetric algorithm” where the security of the algorithm is based on any of the following:

content.html: 2.b.1. Factorization of integers in excess of 512 bits (e.g., RSA);
content.text: 2.b.1. Factorization of integers in excess of 512 bits (e.g., RSA);

content.html: 2.b.2. Computation of discrete logarithms in a multiplicative group of a finite field of size greater than 512 bits (e.g., Diffie-Hellman over Z/pZ); or
content.text: 2.b.2. Computation of discrete logarithms in a multiplicative group of a finite field of size greater than 512 bits (e.g., Diffie-Hellman over Z/pZ); or

content.html: 2.b.3. Discrete logarithms in a group other than mentioned in paragraph 2.b.2 of this Technical Note in excess of 112 bits (e.g., Diffie-Hellman over an elliptic curve); or
content.text: 2.b.3. Discrete logarithms in a group other than mentioned in paragraph 2.b.2 of this Technical Note in excess of 112 bits (e.g., Diffie-Hellman over an elliptic curve); or

content.html: 2.c. An “asymmetric algorithm” where the security of the algorithm is based on any of the following:
content.text: 2.c. An “asymmetric algorithm” where the security of the algorithm is based on any of the following:

content.html: 2.c.1. Shortest vector or closest vector problems associated with lattices (e.g., NewHope, Frodo, NTRUEncrypt, Kyber, Titanium);
content.text: 2.c.1. Shortest vector or closest vector problems associated with lattices (e.g., NewHope, Frodo, NTRUEncrypt, Kyber, Titanium);

content.html: 2.c.2. Finding isogenies between Supersingular elliptic curves (e.g., Supersingular Isogeny Key Encapsulation); or
content.text: 2.c.2. Finding isogenies between Supersingular elliptic curves (e.g., Supersingular Isogeny Key Encapsulation); or

content.html: 2.c.3. Decoding random codes (e.g., McEliece, Niederreiter).
content.text: 2.c.3. Decoding random codes (e.g., McEliece, Niederreiter).

content.html:
Technical Note:

An algorithm described by Technical Note 2.c. may be referred to as being post-quantum, quantum-safe or quantum-resistant.
content.text: Technical Note: An algorithm described by Technical Note 2.c. may be referred to as being post-quantum, quantum-safe or quantum-resistant.

  2. Whether the cryptographic capability for data confidentiality specified by 5A002.a is usable without “cryptographic activation.”

Routers, switches or relays, where the “information security” functionality is limited to the tasks of “Operations, Administration or Maintenance” (“OAM”) implementing only published or commercial cryptographic standards; i. General purpose computing equipment or servers, where the “information security” functionality meets all of the following: i.1. Uses only published or commercial cryptographic standards; and i.2. Is any of the following: i.2.a. Integral to a CPU that meets the provisions of Note 3 in Category 5 - Part 2; i.2.b. Integral to an operating system that is not specified by 5D002; or i.2.c. Limited to “OAM” of the equipment; or j. Items specially designed for a 'connected civil industry application', meeting all of the following: j.1. Being any of the following: j.1.a. A network-capable endpoint device meeting any of the following: j.1.a.1. The “information security” functionality is limited to securing 'non-arbitrary data' or the tasks of “Operations, Administration or Maintenance” (“OAM”); or j.1.a.2. The device is limited to a specific 'connected civil industry application'; or j.1.b. Networking equipment meeting all of the following: j.1.b.1. Being specially designed to communicate with the devices specified by paragraph j.1.a above; and j.1.b.2. The “information security” functionality is limited to supporting the 'connected civil industry application' of devices specified by paragraph j.1.a above, or the tasks of “OAM” of this networking equipment or of other items specified by paragraph j. of this Note; and j.2. Where the “information security” functionality implements only published or commercial cryptographic standards, and the cryptographic functionality cannot easily be changed by the user. Technical Notes: 1. 'Connected civil industry application' means a network-connected consumer or civil industry application other than “information security”, digital communication, general purpose networking or computing. 2. 'Non-arbitrary data' means sensor or metering data directly related to the stability, performance or physical measurement of a system (e.g., temperature, pressure, flow rate, mass, volume, voltage, physical location, etc.), that cannot be changed by the user of the device.

content.html: Technical Notes:
content.text: Technical Notes:

content.html: 1. For the purposes of 5A002.a, 'cryptography for data confidentiality' means “cryptography” that employs digital techniques and performs any cryptographic function other than any of the following:
content.text: 1. For the purposes of 5A002.a, 'cryptography for data confidentiality' means “cryptography” that employs digital techniques and performs any cryptographic function other than any of the following:

content.html: 1.a. “Authentication;”
content.text: 1.a. “Authentication;”

content.html: 1.b. Digital signature;
content.text: 1.b. Digital signature;

content.html: 1.c. Data integrity;
content.text: 1.c. Data integrity;

content.html: 1.d. Non-repudiation;
content.text: 1.d. Non-repudiation;

content.html: 1.e. Digital rights management, including the execution of copy-protected “software;”
content.text: 1.e. Digital rights management, including the execution of copy-protected “software;”

content.html: 1.f. Encryption or decryption in support of entertainment, mass commercial broadcasts or medical records management; or
content.text: 1.f. Encryption or decryption in support of entertainment, mass commercial broadcasts or medical records management; or

content.html: 1.g. Key management in support of any function described in paragraphs 1.a to 1.f of this Technical Note paragraph 1.
content.text: 1.g. Key management in support of any function described in paragraphs 1.a to 1.f of this Technical Note paragraph 1.

content.html: 2. For the purposes of 5A002.a, 'described security algorithm' means any of the following:
content.text: 2. For the purposes of 5A002.a, 'described security algorithm' means any of the following:

content.html: 2.a. A “symmetric algorithm” employing a key length in excess of 56 bits, not including parity bits;
content.text: 2.a. A “symmetric algorithm” employing a key length in excess of 56 bits, not including parity bits;

content.html: 2.b. An “asymmetric algorithm” where the security of the algorithm is based on any of the following:
content.text: 2.b. An “asymmetric algorithm” where the security of the algorithm is based on any of the following:

content.html: 2.b.1. Factorization of integers in excess of 512 bits (e.g., RSA);
content.text: 2.b.1. Factorization of integers in excess of 512 bits (e.g., RSA);

content.html: 2.b.2. Computation of discrete logarithms in a multiplicative group of a finite field of size greater than 512 bits (e.g., Diffie-Hellman over Z/pZ); or
content.text: 2.b.2. Computation of discrete logarithms in a multiplicative group of a finite field of size greater than 512 bits (e.g., Diffie-Hellman over Z/pZ); or

content.html: 2.b.3. Discrete logarithms in a group other than mentioned in paragraph 2.b.2 of this Technical Note in excess of 112 bits (e.g., Diffie-Hellman over an elliptic curve); or
content.text: 2.b.3. Discrete logarithms in a group other than mentioned in paragraph 2.b.2 of this Technical Note in excess of 112 bits (e.g., Diffie-Hellman over an elliptic curve); or

content.html: 2.c. An “asymmetric algorithm” where the security of the algorithm is based on any of the following:
content.text: 2.c. An “asymmetric algorithm” where the security of the algorithm is based on any of the following:

content.html: 2.c.1. Shortest vector or closest vector problems associated with lattices (e.g., NewHope, Frodo, NTRUEncrypt, Kyber, Titanium);
content.text: 2.c.1. Shortest vector or closest vector problems associated with lattices (e.g., NewHope, Frodo, NTRUEncrypt, Kyber, Titanium);

content.html: 2.c.2. Finding isogenies between Supersingular elliptic curves (e.g., Supersingular Isogeny Key Encapsulation); or
content.text: 2.c.2. Finding isogenies between Supersingular elliptic curves (e.g., Supersingular Isogeny Key Encapsulation); or

content.html: 2.c.3. Decoding random codes (e.g., McEliece, Niederreiter).
content.text: 2.c.3. Decoding random codes (e.g., McEliece, Niederreiter).

content.html:
Technical Note:

An algorithm described by Technical Note 2.c. may be referred to as being post-quantum, quantum-safe or quantum-resistant.
content.text: Technical Note: An algorithm described by Technical Note 2.c. may be referred to as being post-quantum, quantum-safe or quantum-resistant.

content.html:
Note 1:

Details of items must be accessible and provided upon request, in order to establish any of the following:

  1. Whether the item meets the criteria of 5A002.a.1, 5A002.a.2, 5A002.a.3, 5A002.a.4; or

  2. Whether the cryptographic capability for data confidentiality specified by 5A002.a is usable without “cryptographic activation.”

Whether the item meets the criteria of 5A002.a.1, 5A002.a.2, 5A002.a.3, 5A002.a.4; or b. Whether the cryptographic capability for data confidentiality specified by 5A002.a is usable without “cryptographic activation.”

  1. Portable or mobile radiotelephones for civil use (e.g., for use with commercial civil cellular radio communication systems) that are not capable of transmitting encrypted data directly to another radiotelephone or equipment (other than Radio Access Network (RAN) equipment), nor of passing encrypted data through RAN equipment (e.g., Radio Network Controller (RNC) or Base Station Controller (BSC));

  2. Cordless telephone equipment not capable of end-to-end encryption where the maximum effective range of unboosted cordless operation (i.e., a single, unrelayed hop between terminal and home base station) is less than 400 meters according to the manufacturer's specifications;

  3. Portable or mobile radiotelephones and similar client wireless devices for civil use, that implement only published or commercial cryptographic standards (except for anti-piracy functions, which may be non-published) and also meet the provisions of paragraphs a.2 to a.4 of the Cryptography Note (Note 3 in Category 5 - Part 2), that have been customized for a specific civil industry application with features that do not affect the cryptographic functionality of these original non-customized devices;

  4. Items, where the “information security” functionality is limited to wireless “personal area network” functionality, meeting all of the following:

    1. f.1. Implement only published or commercial cryptographic standards; and

    2. f.2. The cryptographic capability is limited to a nominal operating range not exceeding 30 meters according to the manufacturer's specifications, or not exceeding 100 meters according to the manufacturer's specifications for equipment that cannot interconnect with more than seven devices;

Mobile telecommunications Radio Access Network (RAN) equipment designed for civil use, which also meet the provisions of paragraphs a.2 to a.4 of the Cryptography Note (Note 3 in Category 5 - Part 2), having an RF output power limited to 0.1W (20 dBm) or less, and supporting 16 or fewer concurrent users;

  6. Routers, switches or relays, where the “information security” functionality is limited to the tasks of “Operations, Administration or Maintenance” (“OAM”) implementing only published or commercial cryptographic standards;

  7. General purpose computing equipment or servers, where the “information security” functionality meets all of the following:

    1. i.1. Uses only published or commercial cryptographic standards; and

    2. i.2. Is any of the following:

    2. j.1.a.2. The device is limited to a specific 'connected civil industry application'; or

  13. j.1.b. Networking equipment meeting all of the following:

    1. j.1.b.1. Being specially designed to communicate with the devices specified by paragraph j.1.a above; and

    2. j.1.b.2. The “information security” functionality is limited to supporting the 'connected civil industry application' of devices specified by paragraph j.1.a above, or the tasks of “OAM” of this networking equipment or of other items specified by paragraph j. of this Note; and

    3. j.2. Where the “information security” functionality implements only published or commercial cryptographic standards, and the cryptographic functionality cannot easily be changed by the user.

content.text: Technical Note to paragraph a.2 of Note 2: 'Readers/writers' include equipment that communicates with smart cards or electronically readable documents through a network. b. Cryptographic equipment specially designed and limited for banking use or 'money transactions';

content.html:
Technical Note to paragraph b. of Note 2:

'Money transactions' in 5A002 Note 2 paragraph b. includes the collection and settlement of fares or credit functions.

  1. Portable or mobile radiotelephones for civil use (e.g., for use with commercial civil cellular radio communication systems) that are not capable of transmitting encrypted data directly to another radiotelephone or equipment (other than Radio Access Network (RAN) equipment), nor of passing encrypted data through RAN equipment (e.g., Radio Network Controller (RNC) or Base Station Controller (BSC));

  2. Cordless telephone equipment not capable of end-to-end encryption where the maximum effective range of unboosted cordless operation (i.e., a single, unrelayed hop between terminal and home base station) is less than 400 meters according to the manufacturer's specifications;

  3. Portable or mobile radiotelephones and similar client wireless devices for civil use, that implement only published or commercial cryptographic standards (except for anti-piracy functions, which may be non-published) and also meet the provisions of paragraphs a.2 to a.4 of the Cryptography Note (Note 3 in Category 5 - Part 2), that have been customized for a specific civil industry application with features that do not affect the cryptographic functionality of these original non-customized devices;

  4. Items, where the “information security” functionality is limited to wireless “personal area network” functionality, meeting all of the following:

    1. f.1. Implement only published or commercial cryptographic standards; and

    2. f.2. The cryptographic capability is limited to a nominal operating range not exceeding 30 meters according to the manufacturer's specifications, or not exceeding 100 meters according to the manufacturer's specifications for equipment that cannot interconnect with more than seven devices;

  5. Mobile telecommunications Radio Access Network (RAN) equipment designed for civil use, which also meet the provisions of paragraphs a.2 to a.4 of the Cryptography Note (Note 3 in Category 5 - Part 2), having an RF output power limited to 0.1W (20 dBm) or less, and supporting 16 or fewer concurrent users;

  6. Routers, switches or relays, where the “information security” functionality is limited to the tasks of “Operations, Administration or Maintenance” (“OAM”) implementing only published or commercial cryptographic standards;

  7. General purpose computing equipment or servers, where the “information security” functionality meets all of the following:

    1. i.1. Uses only published or commercial cryptographic standards; and

    2. i.2. Is any of the following:

  8. i.2.a. Integral to a CPU that meets the provisions of Note 3 in Category 5 - Part 2;

  9. i.2.b. Integral to an operating system that is not specified by 5D002; or

  10. i.2.c. Limited to “OAM” of the equipment; or

  11. Items specially designed for a 'connected civil industry application', meeting all of the following:

    1. j.1. Being any of the following:

  12. j.1.a. A network-capable endpoint device meeting any of the following:

    1. j.1.a.1. The “information security” functionality is limited to securing 'non-arbitrary data' or the tasks of “Operations, Administration or Maintenance” (“OAM”); or

    2. j.1.a.2. The device is limited to a specific 'connected civil industry application'; or

  13. j.1.b. Networking equipment meeting all of the following:

    1. j.1.b.1. Being specially designed to communicate with the devices specified by paragraph j.1.a above; and

    2. j.1.b.2. The “information security” functionality is limited to supporting the 'connected civil industry application' of devices specified by paragraph j.1.a above, or the tasks of “OAM” of this networking equipment or of other items specified by paragraph j. of this Note; and

    3. j.2. Where the “information security” functionality implements only published or commercial cryptographic standards, and the cryptographic functionality cannot easily be changed by the user.

Technical Notes:

1. 'Connected civil industry application' means a network-connected consumer or civil industry application other than “information security”, digital communication, general purpose networking or computing.

2. 'Non-arbitrary data' means sensor or metering data directly related to the stability, performance or physical measurement of a system (e.g., temperature, pressure, flow rate, mass, volume, voltage, physical location, etc.), that cannot be changed by the user of the device.
